Cartesian Product
Let $M$ be a set. The Cartesian product of $M$ with itself, denoted as $M \times M$, is the set of all ordered pairs of elements from $M$.
Order of a group
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
Integral Domain
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
Principal Ideal Domain
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.
Euclidean function
The map $\delta$ in a Euclidean domain $R$ that facilitates the Euclidean division process.
Submodule
Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
Separable Polynomial
A separable polynomial is a polynomial that has distinct roots in its splitting field, i.e., all roots are simple.
Ring Homomorphism of Finite Type

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is of finite type if there exists an epimorphism $\Phi: A[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}] \longrightarrow B$ from a polynomial ring in finitely many variables over $A$ to $B$ that extends $\varphi$. Alternatively, it can be characterized by the existence of elements $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in B$ such that $B=\varphi(A)[x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}]$.
Extension Field

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.
Group Action

Let $G$ be a group and $X$ a set. An action or an operation of $G$ on $X$ is a map $G \times X \longrightarrow X, \quad(g, x) \longmapsto g \cdot x$ such that: (i) $1 \cdot x=x$ for the unit element $1 \in G$ and for elements $x \in X$. (ii) $(g h) \cdot x=g \cdot(h \cdot x)$ for $g, h \in G, x \in X$.
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A principal ideal domain is defined as an integral domain where every ideal is principal. Thus, the concept of an integral domain must be defined to understand what a principal ideal domain is.

A submodule is defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M. Therefore, the concept of a module must be defined to understand what a submodule is.

A ring homomorphism of finite type involves the concept of a ring and polynomial rings over a ring. Therefore, the concept of a ring must be defined to understand what a ring homomorphism of finite type is.

An extension field is defined as a field consisting of a certain number of elements, characterized as a splitting field of a polynomial over another field. Therefore, the concept of a field must be defined to understand what an extension field is.

A group action is defined as a map from the Cartesian product of a group and a set to the set itself. Therefore, the concept of a Cartesian product must be defined to understand what a group action is.
